unnormalised: ## Dodging Challans: A Layman's Guide to Indian Traffic Regulations (aka, How Not to Get Fined by Sharma Ji!)
normalised: ## Dodging Challans: A Layman's Guide to Indian Traffic Regulations (aka, How Not to Get Fined by Sharma Ji!)

unnormalised: Hey folks! Ever felt like understanding Indian traffic regulations is like trying to understand the plot of a Bollywood movie with 5 flashbacks and a dance number every 10 minutes? Yeah, me too! But fear not, because your friendly neighbourhood auto enthusiast is here to break it down (relatively) simply.
normalised: Hey folks! Ever felt like understanding Indian traffic regulations is like trying to understand the plot of a Bollywood movie with five flashbacks and a dance number every ten minutes? Yeah, me too! But fear not, because your friendly neighbourhood auto enthusiast is here to break it down (relatively) simply.

unnormalised: First things first, remember the basics. Red light means *rukho*, green means *jao*, and orange means...well, that's up for debate, isn't it? (Just kidding! Slow down, people!). Speed limits are super important, especially in residential areas. You don't want to be that guy zooming through Sector 17 at 80 km/h, right? Gurgaon cops are pretty strict about that stuff these days.

Speed limits are super important, especially in residential areas. You don't want to be that guy zooming through Sector seventeen at eighty kilometer per hour, right? Gurgaon cops are pretty strict about that stuff these days.

unnormalised: Then there's the whole document drama. Make sure you have your license (duh!), registration certificate (RC), insurance, and PUC certificate handy. Keep them in the car, digital copies are usually fine, but having physical copies is always a good backup, especially during random *naka bandi* checks. Dr. Patil from my apartment society learned that the hard way when he forgot his insurance certificate at home!

Doctor Patil from my apartment society learned that the hard way when he forgot his insurance certificate at home!

unnormalised: And don't even THINK about drinking and driving. The fines are hefty (like, *really* hefty – upwards of Rs. 10,000 in some cases), and honestly, it's just plain irresponsible. Book a cab, call a friend, walk (if you're not too far), anything but get behind the wheel after a few Kingfishers.
normalised: And don't even THINK about drinking and driving. The fines are hefty (like, really hefty – upwards of rupee ten thousand in some cases), and honestly, it's just plain irresponsible. Book a cab, call a friend, walk (if you're not too far), anything but get behind the wheel after a few Kingfishers.

unnormalised: Also, helmet for two-wheelers is non-negotiable! Doesn't matter if you're just popping down to the *kirana* store a few blocks away. Think of it as a stylish (debatable, I know) accessory rather than a hassle. And finally, parking! Look for designated parking areas. Don't be *that* guy who parks his Innova in a "No Parking" zone, blocking the entire road. You'll end up with a wheel clamp and a hefty fine, plus the wrath of Sharma Ji, who owns the corner *chai* stall and sees everything! Plus you may block a 100 sq ft of space for others to park. Safe driving, folks! And may the *challan* gods be ever in your favour.
